awd_titl_txt: CAREER TRAJECTORIES OF STEM DOCTORAL STUDENTS: AN EXPLORATORY STUDY OF LATENT GROUPS USING CULTURALLY RESPONSIVE MEASURES AND METHODS
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project focuses on understanding the experiences and perspectives of marginalized groups in STEM fields. Three aims frame the project team's research plan. First is to examine factors that influence and predict career trajectories of subgroups of STEM doctoral students and graduates based on their career motivations and aspirations. Second is to develop and integrate culturally responsive student and context-level measures to investigate the career pathways of STEM PhD students. Third is to validate survey measures for marginalized groups in STEM. Thus framed, the project offers both substantive and methodological contributions. In the first case, the project holds promise to provide novel empirical evidence to understand STEM students’ career trajectories, the mechanisms and factors that influence them, and variability across diverse subgroups. In the second case, the project seeks to develop new measures and scales associated with Social Cognitive Career Theory (SCCT), evaluating their psychometric properties and evaluating their operation and utility across diverse populations. Moreover, the study results could address key shortcomings in current quantitative analyses of STEM graduate training and career development.

The project's principal investigators will employ a mixed-methods research design to answer three sets of research questions: (1) What discreet sub-populations can be identified based on the career motivations and objectives of STEM PhD students and recent graduates? What are the characteristics of each sub-population? (2) What individual proximal and broader social factors influence the career trajectories of STEM Ph.D. students and recent graduates within each sub-population? Why? (3) Does evidence support the construct and cross-group validity of the survey constructs adapted and developed for this study? The investigators will collect survey data from current and recent doctoral students of three North Carolina institutions and analyze the data set using regression mixture modeling. The study results could inform policies and practices to expand the pipeline for diverse STEM doctoral students. 

The project is funded by the EHR Core Research (ECR) program. ECR supports fundamental STEM education research projects that address issues relevant to STEM learning and learning environments, broadening participation in STEM fields, and STEM workforce development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview 

Understanding the diverse ecosystems and groups of career decision makers among STEM PhD students and recent graduates was a significant gap in research that his project investigated, with funding from the National Science Foundation (award #2226007). This study employed culturally responsive understandings and measures to investigate myriad factors influencing career motivations, job-related aspirations, and career-related trajectories among STEM PhD students and recent graduates with a particular focus on perspectives and experiences informed by those historically excluded within the STEM enterprise. 

Research Questions

To investigate this area, NORC at the University of Chicago (NORC) utilized a mixed-methods approach to answer three research questions:

  • Does evidence support the construct and cross-group validity of the seven survey constructs adapted and developed for this study (i.e., self-efficacy, identity within academic field, career motivations, and various socio-historical contextual factors)?
  • What discrete groups of career decision makers can be identified based on the career motivations and job-related aspirations of STEM PhD students and recent graduates? What are the characteristics of each of these groups?
  • What individual and contextual factors influence the career trajectories of STEM PhD students and recent graduates within each of the groups of career decision makers? Why?

Approach

The study was conducted in partnership with North Carolina Agricultural and Technical State University (NC A&T), North Carolina State University (NC State) and The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (UNC-Chapel Hill), and proceeded in three distinct phases:

  • Phase 1 (survey): we developed and administered an online survey and analyzed the data using exploratory and confirmatory factor analyses, latent class analyses, and regression mixture modeling;
  • Phase 2 (focus groups): we conducted focus groups to further explore and understand the survey results; and
  • Phase 3 (data integration): we triangulated findings from Phase 1 and Phase 2 to comprehensively answer the study’s research questions. 

The study concluded with several key findings based on data collected from a total of 2,097 survey participants (who completed the survey between April–June 2023) and a total of 96 focus group participants (who participated in a focus group between January–May 2024). 

Key Findings

We highlight three key findings from our project:

  • Survey Measure Effectiveness: The study confirmed the construct and cross-group validity of the survey measures for the overall sample as well as across groups based on enrollment status, marginalized/non-marginalized race/ethnicity, and marginalized/non-marginalized gender. It also illuminated possible areas to conceptually and methodologically expand these measures for future survey-based research.
  • Identification of Career Decision-making Groups: The research successfully identified six distinct groups of STEM doctoral students and graduates based on their career motivations and job-related aspirations. This segmentation highlighted various characteristics of distinct groups of STEM career decision makers.
  • Identification of Intrapersonal and Contextual Factors Influencing STEM Career Trajectories: The study illuminated various individual and environmental factors such as academic experiences, mentorship, institutional support, and personal aspirations that influence the career trajectories across groups of career decision makers.

Intellectual Merit 

The project contributed both substantively and methodologically to this area of inquiry. Substantively, we expanded on existing theories and research on STEM PhD students’ career trajectories. In particular, we broadened social cognitive career theory (SCCT) by: 1) integrating and investigating the impacts of culturally responsive variables on PhD students’ and recent graduates’ career pathways, and 2) examining the potential impacts of broader socio-political factors on career decision making. From a fundamental research perspective, these contributions provide the STEM enterprise novel empirical evidence to understand career trajectories within the STEM enterprise, mechanisms and factors that influence these paths, and variability across diverse groups of STEM career decision makers. Additionally, this project made important methodological contributions by developing or adapting new survey measures, evaluating their psychometric properties, and validating their operation and utility across diverse STEM populations. 

Boader Impacts for STEM Graduate Education 

For decades, outcome data demonstrate that STEM PhD students follow a variety of career paths. This exploratory study pursued the under-researched question of what drives the diverging career decisions made by STEM PhD students and recent graduates and what factors shape those divergent paths. These research findings highlight a need to understand more deeply the potential of institutional factors, such as career mentoring and professional development programs, in reinforcing the career convictions of STEM PhD-level trainees. The qualitative component of our research particularly emphasized the extent to which mentoring, research opportunities, conferences, research collaborations, publication experiences, and funding all contribute to current and former PhD students’ ability to do research in their fields. And across all focus groups, mentoring was the most frequently cited catalyst for developing research-related capabilities. 

The study’s findings underscore the need to further understand and support various factors within STEM PhD-level trainees’ ecosystems and that these factors are diverse based on trainees’ career-related motivations, job-related aspirations, and a variety of other ecological characteristics.


Last Modified: 12/06/2024
Modified by: James R Neumeister
por.por_txt_cntn:
Overview 


Understanding the diverse ecosystems and groups of career decision makers among STEM PhD students and recent graduates was a significant gap in research that his project investigated, with funding from the National Science Foundation (award #2226007). This study employed culturally responsive understandings and measures to investigate myriad factors influencing career motivations, job-related aspirations, and career-related trajectories among STEM PhD students and recent graduates with a particular focus on perspectives and experiences informed by those historically excluded within the STEM enterprise.


Research Questions 





To investigate this area, NORC at the University of Chicago (NORC) utilized a mixed-methods approach to answer three research questions: 

Does evidence support the construct and cross-group validity of the seven survey constructs adapted and developed for this study (i.e., self-efficacy, identity within academic field, career motivations, and various socio-historical contextual factors)? 
What discrete groups of career decision makers can be identified based on the career motivations and job-related aspirations of STEM PhD students and recent graduates? What are the characteristics of each of these groups? 
What individual and contextual factors influence the career trajectories of STEM PhD students and recent graduates within each of the groups of career decision makers? Why? 






Approach 



The study was conducted in partnership with North Carolina Agricultural and Technical State University (NC A&T), North Carolina State University (NC State) and The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (UNC-Chapel Hill), and proceeded in three distinct phases: 

Phase 1 (survey): we developed and administered an online survey and analyzed the data using exploratory and confirmatory factor analyses, latent class analyses, and regression mixture modeling; 
Phase 2 (focus groups): we conducted focus groups to further explore and understand the survey results; and 
Phase 3 (data integration): we triangulated findings from Phase 1 and Phase 2 to comprehensively answer the studys research questions.







The study concluded with several key findings based on data collected from a total of 2,097 survey participants (who completed the survey between AprilJune 2023) and a total of 96 focus group participants (who participated in a focus group between JanuaryMay 2024).




Key Findings 


We highlight three key findings from our project: 

Survey Measure Effectiveness: The study confirmed the construct and cross-group validity of the survey measures for the overall sample as well as across groups based on enrollment status, marginalized/non-marginalized race/ethnicity, and marginalized/non-marginalized gender. It also illuminated possible areas to conceptually and methodologically expand these measures for future survey-based research.
Identification of Career Decision-making Groups: The research successfully identified six distinct groups of STEM doctoral students and graduates based on their career motivations and job-related aspirations. This segmentation highlighted various characteristics of distinct groups of STEM career decision makers.
Identification of Intrapersonal and Contextual Factors Influencing STEM Career Trajectories: The study illuminated various individual and environmental factors such as academic experiences, mentorship, institutional support, and personal aspirations that influence the career trajectories across groups of career decision makers. 






Intellectual Merit




The project contributed both substantively and methodologically to this area of inquiry. Substantively, we expanded on existing theories and research on STEM PhD students career trajectories. In particular, we broadened social cognitive career theory (SCCT) by: 1) integrating and investigating the impacts of culturally responsive variables on PhD students and recent graduates career pathways, and 2) examining the potential impacts of broader socio-political factors on career decision making. From a fundamental research perspective, these contributions provide the STEM enterprise novel empirical evidence to understand career trajectories within the STEM enterprise, mechanisms and factors that influence these paths, and variability across diverse groups of STEM career decision makers. Additionally, this project made important methodological contributions by developing or adapting new survey measures, evaluating their psychometric properties, and validating their operation and utility across diverse STEM populations.




Boader Impacts for STEM Graduate Education




For decades, outcome data demonstrate that STEM PhD students follow a variety of career paths. This exploratory study pursued the under-researched question of what drives the diverging career decisions made by STEM PhD students and recent graduates and what factors shape those divergent paths. These research findings highlight a need to understand more deeply the potential of institutional factors, such as career mentoring and professional development programs, in reinforcing the career convictions of STEM PhD-level trainees. The qualitative component of our research particularly emphasized the extent to which mentoring, research opportunities, conferences, research collaborations, publication experiences, and funding all contribute to current and former PhD students ability to do research in their fields. And across all focus groups, mentoring was the most frequently cited catalyst for developing research-related capabilities.




The studys findings underscore the need to further understand and support various factors within STEM PhD-level trainees ecosystems and that these factors are diverse based on trainees career-related motivations, job-related aspirations, and a variety of other ecological characteristics.
